column506: >Why I’m Writing About This Today
column510: > Recently, I’ve been having a few back-and-forths on Reddit with folks curious about tax sales. What stood out to me? Almost everyone was more interested in deed sales than liens. It makes sense deeds mean you’re buying the property itself, not just the debt.
column514: > So I figured it was time to share something useful for everyone asking: Which states actually sell tax deeds?
column521: >Tax Deeds vs. Tax Liens — A Quick Refresher
column525: > When someone doesn’t pay property taxes, the county has to recover that money.
column539: > In lien states, they sell a tax lien — basically an IOU secured by the property. Investors collect interest when the taxes are repaid.
column543: > In deed states, they sell the tax deed — which means you’re bidding directly on ownership of the property itself.
column547: >Lien states give you interest. Deed states give you the property. Big difference.
column554: >The Tax Deed Advantage
column558: > Here’s why investors like me (and my team) lean toward deed states:
column572: >Immediate ownership – Win the auction, pay the back taxes, and the deed is yours.
column576: >High upside potential – Properties valued at $100k+ can sometimes start at just a few thousand dollars.
column580: >No multi-year wait – Unlike liens, most deed states don’t have long redemption periods.
column584: > But don’t mistake speed for safety. Mortgages, IRS liens, state liens, and title issues don’t vanish just because you hold the deed. Due diligence is survival in this business.

column725: >(Note: Some are redeemable deed states or hybrids, meaning owners still have a short window to redeem even after the deed is sold.)
column732: >Why This Matters for You
column736: > If you’re serious about tax sales, this list is your starting map. It determines your entire playbook:
column750: > In lien states, you’re mostly after interest income — like a fixed-income investment.
column754: > In deed states, you’re after ownership — which means bigger rewards, but also bigger risks.
column758: > In redeemable deed or hybrid states, you have to factor in short redemption periods or upset-bid processes before you truly own the property.
column762: > I cut my teeth in New Mexico, a deed state. The wins were life-changing , but I also saw deals go sideways fast when investors skipped their homework.
column773: > Think of lien states vs. deed states as two different sports. Both can make you money, but the rules and the risks are completely different.
column777: > If you know the map before you step into the game, you’re already ahead of 90% of people who just “show up” at auctions.

column506: >The Auction Isn’t the Finish Line
column510: > When I first started buying properties at tax sales, I thought winning at the auction was the finish line. Raise your bidder card, pay your money, wait for the deed — boom, you’re a property owner. Ready to call a realtor and cash out, right?
column518: >What Is a Quiet Title Action?
column522: > The county sells you the delinquent owners interest in the property, but that doesn’t mean the title is “clean.” Old mortgages, heirs, IRS liens, or sloppy paperwork can all cloud ownership.
column526:
> A quiet title action is a lawsuit you file to “quiet” all other claims against the property. It’s basically standing in front of a judge saying:
“I bought this property fair and square at a tax sale. If anyone disagrees, speak now or forever hold your peace.”
column547: >Resale value – Without a court order, no title company will insure it.
column551: >Financing – Banks won’t lend against a clouded title.
column555: >Peace of mind – Old liens or heirs? Once the judge signs, they’re gone.
column562: >A Real Example from My Portfolio
column566: > One of my earliest deals in Catron County, NM, drove this home. I bought a vacant cabin on 5 acres for $2,000 at a tax sale. The previous owner had passed away, with heirs scattered across the country. The only way forward was filing a quiet title action.
column570: > They never contested, and I got a default judgment. That one document made all the difference — suddenly I had a property I could rehab, insure, and turn into a successful Airbnb.
column577: >The Cost of Certainty
column581: > Quiet title actions usually run $2,000 to $5,000 or more depending on:
column595: > How complex the title issue is
column599: > Whether it’s contested or uncontested
column603: > Local attorney fees
column607: > They also take time — often 3 months to 6. But without it, you’re holding a property that you can’t fully monetize.
column615: > Buying at a tax sale without a quiet title action is like buying a car without the keys. You technically own it… but good luck driving it anywhere.

column503: > Every time a new sale pops up in Torrance County, I feel a pull back to where it all started for me. This is where I cut my teeth in tax deed investing—and let me tell you, this county has produced some of my best wins. column719: >Why Due Diligence Matters in New Mexico
column723: > This is where a lot of new investors slip up. In New Mexico:
column737: >Mortgages survive the sale. If there’s a recorded mortgage, it doesn’t get wiped out—you take the property with that debt still attached.
column741: >IRS & State Tax Liens: These can also survive, and you don’t want to inherit those unknowingly.
column745: >Judgments & Mechanics Liens: Depending on how they were recorded, these can stick as well.
column749: >Quit Claim Deed Only: The state gives you no warranty of title. It’s on you to clean up issues afterward.
column753: >Microfiche Records: Many counties—including Torrance—still keep old-school archives. You (or someone you hire) may need to be there in person to review the chain of title.
column757: > The bottom line: the numbers may look exciting, but without thorough research, you could end up buying someone else’s problems instead of a hidden gem.

column503: > I came across an article this week that made me stop and think. It’s about a new program called Tax Deeds AI from Tax Lien Wealth Builders — they’re launching nationwide workshops to teach investors how to use their tool to find and analyze tax sale properties faster.
column507: > Here’s the article if you want to read it yourself: Business Insider Coverage.
column511: > The idea is simple: instead of digging through messy county websites for hours, the tool scans property data across counties and flags potential opportunities in minutes. Pair that with workshops and coaching, and suddenly tax deed investing feels more accessible than ever.
column515: > On paper, it sounds like a dream. But you know me — after 12 years in this business, I’ve learned there are always two sides to the story.
column522: >Why Tools Like This Look Promising
column536: >Time saver. Reviewing 100+ properties before a sale? Normally takes a week. With a system like this, it could take a day.
column540: >Confidence boost. New investors get a step-by-step approach instead of drowning in courthouse jargon.
column544: >Broader reach. Instead of focusing on just one county, tools like this let you scan multiple counties across a state.
column548: >Better analysis. Clean, organized data helps spot risks and values faster.The Other Side Nobody Likes to Talk About
column569: >They’re not free. Access comes with a cost, and it adds up if you’re not landing deals.
column573: >Garbage in, garbage out. If county records are wrong or incomplete, the tool is wrong too. IRS liens, state tax liens, mechanical liens, and probate issues can still sneak through.
column577: >Over reliance. It’s tempting to think the tool does the hard work for you. It doesn’t. Nothing replaces boots-on-the-ground due diligence.
column581: >Counties aren’t as advanced as you think. A few big counties have digitized systems, but the vast majority still run on outdated tech. Many still keep records on microfiche or paper files that require you to show up in person. No tool can scan a filing cabinet in a dusty county basement.
column585: >Local quirks. I’ve seen counties in New Mexico and North Carolina handle deeds in ways no national system can fully account for.
column596: > Look, I think Tax Deeds AI is a sign of where this industry is headed — faster research, cleaner data, more tools at our fingertips. And I’m not against it. But I’d treat it like power steering: it makes the drive easier, but you’re still the one behind the wheel.
column600: > If I were starting fresh today, I’d:
column612: > Test a tool like this in one county I know well.
column616: > Cross-check results with my own assessor and clerk research.
column620: > Use it as a filter, not a decision-maker.
column631: > Tech is exciting, and workshops like these will draw attention. But the reality is this: most counties across America are still old-school, and until every record is digitized, nothing replaces being in the courthouse yourself.
column635: > That’s why the smartest investors use a mix — modern tools to save time and traditional methods to make sure nothing slips through the cracks. At the end of the day, courthouse investing still comes down to the same thing it always has: knowing more than the person bidding next to you.

column506: >What Is an “Upset Bid”?
column510: > In North Carolina, every tax sale property enters a 10-day upset bid period after the courthouse auction.
column524: > Anyone can walk into the Clerk of Court’s office and place a new bid.
column528: > Each upset must be at least 5% higher than the current bid OR $750 more (whichever is greater).
column532: > Every new upset bid resets the 10-day countdown.
column536: > The process ends only when 10 full days pass with no new bids.
column540: > That means a property could stay in upset-bid limbo for weeks or even months.
column547: >Why This Matters to Investors
column551: > For professional investors, this system is actually an advantage:
column565: > No courthouse pressure — they can skip the live sale.
column569: > Built-in time for deeper due diligence during each 10-day period.
column573: > Strategic timing — file an upset bid close to the deadline, leaving less time for competitors to respond.
column577: > Real competition happens after the auction, not during it.

>Step 1: Start with the right state
Find out if it’s a tax deed state (you’re bidding on the property itself) or a lien state (you’re bidding on the tax debt).
column528: > Why it matters: in deed states you’re closer to ownership, but rules vary — some have redemption periods, some don’t.
column532:
>Step 2: Narrow down to a county
Every county runs its sales differently. Some are online, some are at the courthouse. Some give you a clean spreadsheet, others upload a scanned PDF that looks like it was typed in 1987.
column536: > Why it matters: the county controls the list, the timing, and the rules.
column540:
>Step 3: Ask for the list
Call or email the Treasurer’s/Tax Collector’s office. It’s as simple as:
column541: class=""dd""><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center"" class=""d"" style=""background-color:#EAEBEC
column547: class=""dd"">
column551: >Hi, I’m interested in your upcoming tax deed sale. Could you send me the sale list and bidder instructions?
column555: > They’ll usually email it to you or point you to the county’s website or auction portal.
column559:
>Step 4: Check the property values
With the list in hand, your next stop is the Assessor’s Office. Plug in the parcel numbers and pull the assessed values, year built, square footage, and land details.
column563: > Why it’s important: assessed value market value, but it gives you a quick baseline. From there, check market comps online (Zillow, Redfin, local MLS if you can).
column567:
>Step 5: Dig into the records
Now comes the part that separates serious bidders from casual ones. Head over (virtually, if possible) to the County Clerk/Recorder and search:
column581: > Mortgages or deeds of trust
column585: > HOA or municipal liens
column589: >IRS tax liens (often supersede the sale and do not get wiped out)
column593: >State tax liens (many also survive the sale)
column597: >Mechanic’s liens (contractor claims for unpaid work — can cloud title)
column605: > Judgments or lawsuits
column609: > REC (real estate contracts)
column613: > This tells you if you’re buying a clean property or stepping into someone else’s mess.
column617:
>Step 6: Check the courts
Look at the county court system (and federal PACER) for:
column631: > Bankruptcies (these can pause or block sales)
column635: > Active lawsuits (foreclosure, code enforcement, quiet title issues)
column639: > Probate cases tied to the property
column643:
>Step 7: Put eyes on the property
If you’re not local, don’t worry — tech helps.
column657: > Use Google Maps, Street View, and Earth
column661: > Check roof, access, terrain, neighborhood
column665: > Confirm parcel shape and access on the county GIS map
column669: > Hire a local runner or agent for drive-by photos if it’s serious
column676: >Bonus Tip: Title Companies
column680: > If you’re new or nervous about digging through liens yourself, you can hire a local title company to do the research for you.
column684: > Most charge around $100 per property to pull a lien search. That can get pricey if you’re reviewing hundreds of parcels, which is exactly why I recommend learning how to do it yourself.
column688: > Once you get comfortable reading mortgages, liens, and probates, you’ll save thousands — and move much faster than waiting on a third party.
column699: > Getting the list is only the first step — the real advantage comes from doing the homework most bidders skip. By the time auction day rolls around, you’ll know which properties are worth fighting for and which ones to cross off fast.
column703: > We’ll save the bidding process for the next issue.

column506: >Guest Author: Tricia Jacobs, Tax Lien Investor
column510: > This week I’m handing the mic to Tricia Jacobs, an experienced tax lien investor who’s been working auctions across New England. She’s seen firsthand how Connecticut’s lien market offers double-digit returns most investors don’t even know exist.
column514: > Here’s Tricia’s breakdown:
column521: >Why I Focus on Connecticut Liens
column525: > Most people chase the stock market or rental properties. But in Connecticut, tax liens consistently offer 18% annual returns—guaranteed by statute.
column551: >CT Tax Liens: 18% if redeemed
column555: > I don’t know many other legal, predictable ways to double that kind of return without tenants or Wall Street volatility.
column566: > When property owners miss their tax bills, municipalities sell tax lien certificates to investors.
column580: > You step in and cover the unpaid taxes.
column584: > The owner now owes you, plus 18% interest.
column588: > Typical lien sizes run $800 to $6,000 in Eastern Connecticut.
column592: > If they pay, you collect your interest. If they don’t, you can eventually foreclose and take the property.

column625: >High Redemption Rates (70–85%): Most owners pay back, meaning predictable income.
column629: >Urban Opportunities: In Hartford, Bridgeport, and New Haven, some owners don’t redeem—opening the door to foreclosures.
column633: >Eastern CT Advantage: Lower property values, less competition, and smaller certificates.
column637: > It’s a market with room for both conservative investors (just chasing the interest) and those hoping to acquire property.
column658: >Rental Property: 8–12% return (plus headaches).
column662: >Stocks: 10% on average, but volatile.
column666: >Tax Liens: 18% on paper, with the possibility of ending up with a house if redemption doesn’t happen.
column670: > It’s not glamorous, but it’s steady—and in a world of shaky markets, that consistency matters.
column691: > Attend a few sales as an observer.
column695: > Start small—$1,000 to $5,000 is plenty.
column699: > Learn one or two towns well (every municipality runs slightly differently).
column703: > Be patient. Many redemptions take 12–24 months.
column707: > Thanks to Tricia for pulling back the curtain on Connecticut’s tax lien market.
column711: > If you’d like to hear more from her and other investors in the field, stay tuned—because over the next few weeks, I’ll be bringing you more firsthand stories from the courthouse steps.

column503: > I want to walk you through a real example from this week’s auction list in Kootenai County, Idaho.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column523: > The county had scheduled a 10-acre property at 8700 E Morning Glory Ave, Athol, ID for its September tax deed sale.
column527: > Here’s why it caught my attention:
column541: >3-bed, 1,700 sq ft home with garage (built in 1998)
column545: >10 acres of land — a rare find in North Idaho
column557: > On paper, that’s the kind of spread that makes tax deed auctions so powerful. Imagine securing a property with that much equity for pennies on the dollar.
column561: > But here’s what happened: the owner redeemed the property before the sale.
column565: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column580: > When you hear the term “redemption,” it simply means the owner came up with the money to cover their delinquent taxes, fees, and interest — and stopped the property from being auctioned.
column584: > Counties want tax revenue, not your property. If the owner pays before the sale date, the property is pulled from the list.
column588: > This happens all the time, and it’s an important part of the process to understand as an investor.
column595: >Redemption Periods: The Investor’s Friend (and Foe)
column599: > Different states handle redemption differently:
column613: >Tax Liens (like Arizona, Illinois, Florida): You’re buying the debt, not the property. Owners usually have a redemption period (1–3 years) to pay you back with interest. That’s your profit.
column617: >Tax Deeds (like Idaho, Texas, Georgia): The county sells the property itself. Some states (like Georgia and Texas) have a post-sale redemption period, meaning the owner can still buy back the property within 6–12 months — often with a penalty that becomes your profit.
column621: >Idaho’s Case: Once the redemption deadline passes, the property goes to auction. If it redeems before auction day, it’s gone — like what we saw with Morning Glory Ave.
column625: > So as exciting as it is to see properties listed at jaw-dropping discounts, you’ve got to remember: redemptions are built into the system.
column632: >Why This Is Still a Win for You
column636: > Even though you couldn’t bid on this property, every redemption is proof of two things:
column648: >The system works. Counties collect taxes, schools and fire departments stay funded, and you know these auctions will keep happening.
column652: >The pipeline stays full. If one property redeems, another will pop up. Your edge as an investor comes from being consistent and staying ready.
column655: class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column660: >Bottom line: Morning Glory didn’t hit the auction block, but the lesson is just as valuable as the deal. Learn how redemptions work, know your state’s rules, and you’ll never be surprised when a property disappears at the last minute.

column503: > On July 4, 2025, President Trump mentioned the idea of eliminating property taxes. It caught headlines everywhere, and for a moment you might have thought: what would that mean for me as an investor?
column507: > Here’s the truth: property taxes aren’t going anywhere. They’re the backbone of county revenue, and without them, schools, police, and fire departments couldn’t function.
column511: > So, what’s the real takeaway for you as a tax deed or lien investor? Let me walk you through why property taxes will remain, and why that creates steady opportunity if you know where to look.
column518: >1. Property Taxes Are Decided Locally
column522: > Property taxes are controlled by counties and municipalities, not the federal government. That means Washington doesn’t dictate whether your local county holds a tax sale. For you, this is important: no matter what’s said on a national stage, those courthouse auctions on the first Tuesday of the month? They’ll still be there.
column529: >2. They Fund the Services You Rely On
column533: > Property taxes make up about 30% of all state and local revenue—that’s over $600 billion each year. Those dollars pay for schools, maintain roads, and keep public safety funded. If those dollars went away, counties would have no choice but to replace them with something else. And that replacement would almost certainly still involve enforcing payment through liens and deed sales.
column540: >3. Aspirational Promises Don’t Change the System
column544: > Political leaders often share bold ideas to inspire people. But the mechanics of property taxes are deeply rooted in local government finance. Even if the discussion continues at the national level, the reality is that tax systems and auctions are managed at the county level. Your investing opportunities remain grounded in that fact.
column551: >4. The Math Doesn’t Add Up for Elimination
column555: > Regardless of politics, eliminating property taxes outright would mean asking someone else—likely the federal government—to replace billions in annual revenue. That kind of shift simply isn’t realistic today. As an investor, that means stability: tax sales are here to stay because counties depend on them.
column562: >5. What This Means for Your Investment Strategy
column566: > Instead of wondering whether property taxes will vanish, focus on what’s already in front of you. Every year, thousands of properties go unpaid, counties pursue collection, and auctions happen. Those auctions are where your opportunities are.
column570: > The more you understand your county’s process—how redemption works, how deed sales are scheduled, and where to pull delinquent lists—the more you can take advantage while others are distracted by national headlines.
column591: > Property taxes aren’t disappearing.
column595: > That means tax deed and lien sales will remain a reliable source of opportunity.
column599: > Your edge comes from doing the research at the county level while others speculate about big-picture politics.
column610: > Take 15 minutes this week to visit your county treasurer’s website. Look up the most recent delinquent property list, and note the next auction date. The list you pull today could become the deal that changes your investment portfolio tomorrow.

column448: >The Setup: One Week of Due Diligence
column452: > Picture this: a team of five real estate investors (including me) huddled in Grant County, NM.
column456:
> We had one mission: review the tax sale list.
Over 110 properties were scheduled to hit the auction block for delinquent taxes.
column460: > So we camped out in the County Clerk’s office, digging through every record we could find — probate filings, municipal liens, mortgages, you name it. Hours of flipping pages and cross-checking documents just to figure out which properties were worth chasing at Monday’s 9:00 a.m. sale.
column467: >The Property That Stood Out
column471: > One house jumped off the list.
column485: > Assessed at $198K by the county
column489: > Sitting on two acres (one with the house, one in the back)
column493: > Built in 1985 by a well-known ranching family who once owned 10,000 acres nearby
column497:
> Stephen, one of the guys on my team, looked at me and asked:
“Any liens? Mortgages?”
column504: >The Red Flag… or an Opportunity?
column508: > After a full day of digging, here’s what I found:
column522: > A small local bank, A***** Financial**, held a mortgage.
column526: > That bank collapsed during the 2008 crash.
column530: > Before then, the property had shifted hands under a REC (Real Estate Contract).
column534: > It looked messy. And messy usually scares investors.
column538: > But here’s the twist: JP Morgan Chase had acquired the failed bank. And when they transferred the mortgage, they completely botched the paperwork — wrong legal description, wrong county recording.
column542: > For me, that wasn’t a red flag. That was a door opening.
column553: > Everyone else wanted to pass, but I pushed to see the house in person.
column557: > We drove 10 miles outside the city toward the municipal airport. And there it was: Airport Rd.
column561: > Concrete walls solid. Metal roof intact. Porch, stone wall fencing, Fireplace, even a pond out front. Sure, abandoned… but you could see the bones were strong.
column565: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column573: > I even tracked down the grandson of the original owner. We knocked on his door, and he walked us through the property’s story.
column584: > At 8:00 a.m., our team met at the County Admin building to finalize bids. I told them flat out: “I’m going for this one.”
column588: > They all pushed back. Too risky, too messy, too uncertain.
column592: > But I made up my mind: if nothing else, I’d throw down the opening bid — $4,500 in back taxes.
column596: > By 9:30 a.m., the auction room was packed with 35 people — mostly neighbors and a dozen serious investors I’d seen before.
column600: > When item #66 came up, I hesitated for a moment. The room stayed silent. Then I raised my bidder card.
column604:
> “$4,500,” the auctioneer called.
“Going once… going twice… SOLD! Bidder #7.”

column619: >The Win… and the Storm Ahead
column623: > I was ecstatic. On paper, I had just bought a potential $350K house for $4,500.
column627: > But I knew better — this was just the beginning.
column641: > Years of legal battles
column645: > Headaches from renters
column649: > Lawsuits from banks and REC contract holders
column653: > And yet, in that moment, I was ready.

column548: > The Fairbanks North Star Borough tax foreclosure sale only happens about every two years. For real estate investors, this is one of the few chances to buy Alaska tax foreclosure properties directly from the borough. This year’s auction features 60+ properties, including vacant land and residential parcels.
column555: >How Alaska Tax Foreclosure Sales Work
column569: >3-year process: Property owners who fail to pay delinquent property taxes in Alaska for three years may lose the property through foreclosure.
column573: >Sealed bid format: Unlike a live auction, a sealed bid property auction in Alaska means you submit bids in envelopes. Bids will be opened after 5:00 p.m. on September 10.
column577: >Repurchase rights: Former owners can still redeem their property up until the day of the sale at 5:00 p.m.
column598: > All delinquent property tax payments must be made with guaranteed funds (cash, cashier’s check, money order, or wire transfer).
column602: > Checks must be payable to “FNSB” with the Parcel Account Number (PAN) in the memo line.
column606: > Always confirm details with the Fairbanks North Star Borough Treasury-Budget Division before sending funds.
column613: >Sample Properties Available in 2025 Tax Sale
column627: >1123 Wojo Ave – Assessed $4,318 | Minimum Bid $5,119

column647: >These examples show the range of investment opportunities available in the Fairbanks Alaska tax deed sale.
column666: >Review the official property list from the Borough (request online or by phone).
column670: > Use the assessor’s GIS mapping tool with the Parcel Account Number to confirm lot size, location, and red flags.
column674: > Contact the Treasury-Budget Division at 907-459-1238 or fnsbtax@fnsb.gov for updated payoff amounts and auction details.
column678: > Submit sealed bids for Alaska tax foreclosure properties between Aug 28 – Sept 9 (12–4 p.m.) or on Sept 10 (10 a.m.–5 p.m.).

column531: > When property owners stop paying their property taxes, the county eventually seizes the property and auctions it off.
column545: > You’re bidding on the actual property, not just the debt.
column549: > Some counties require full payment right away
column550: others give you 24–72 hours.
column554: > The catch? You often need to budget for title cleanup (like a quiet title action) before you can sell.
column558: > Why it works: If you do your homework, you can pick up houses and land for 20–40 cents on the dollar.

column573: > Instead of selling the property, some states sell the tax debt itself. You pay the back taxes, and in return, you earn interest when the owner pays you back. If they don’t, you can foreclose and take the property.
column587: > Yields vary — some states pay 8%, 12%, even 18% interest.
column591: > Redemption periods matter: some last months, some years.
column595: > Not every lien leads to a property, but when it does, it can be a big win.
column599: > Why it works: You either make high interest on your money or position yourself to own the property down the road.
column602: class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column614: > In many communities, owners must pay homeowners association (HOA) dues. If they fall behind, the HOA can foreclose — even if the mortgage is current.
column628: > In super-lien states, HOA claims can actually jump ahead of the mortgage.
column632: > You’re usually bidding at much lower amounts — sometimes just the past-due dues plus legal fees.
column636: > The risk? Mortgages and other liens can still survive the HOA sale. You need to know the hierarchy of liens in your state.
column640: > Why it works: Few investors pay attention to HOA sales, so competition is lower.

column655: > These three methods — Tax Deeds, Tax Liens, and HOA Foreclosures — are powerful because they don’t rely on banks, brokers, or traditional financing. They require research and discipline, but once you understand the process, the opportunities are endless.
column659: > Every week in this newsletter, I’ll share one practical insight like this — checklists, case studies, and strategies you can actually use.
